Cornell Tradition Fellowship Award

Alpha Delta Phi Cornell Fellowship Award

Is awarded to undergraduates who demonstrate a commitment to work and service. Current Cornell students, who were not chosen as entering freshmen to be in the Tradition program, may apply in the spring of their freshman/sophomore/junior year to be admitted into the program at the beginning of the next academic year.

Sorority and Fraternity Scholarship

Beta Theta Pi Scholarship

This award is need-based and intended for Greek undergraduates who demonstrate leadership qualities or hold a leadership position in their respective chapter. Students who qualify for grant and work-study through the Cornell Financial Aid Office and demonstrate a significant leadership role in their chapter are eligible to self-nominate. Students who have grant and self-help components in their financial aid package and are selected based on rank order established by the chapter and alumni. Awards are for the following year and graduating seniors are not eligible to apply.

Recognition Status: Full

Judicial History

This chapter has not been found responsible for any judicial violations in the past 5 years or more.

Dr. Susan H. Murphy, Sorority & Fraternity Awards

2020 Randy Scott Stevens Award

This award recognizes a fraternity for outstanding support and contribution to the Cornell Interfraternity Council and for commitment to the ideals of the North-American Interfraternity Conference.

2019 Outstanding Commitment to Community & Inclusion

Dedication to promoting an inclusive community is central to the Cornell Sorority & Fraternity community values. Community incorporates friendship, love, loyalty, and diversity. Organizations should show dedication to inclusive practices in programming and training initiatives. Winners in this category have incorporated inclusive practices to create more comprehensive spaces for students, as well as, the general commitment of members to diversity. Being a part of a fraternity and sorority community is about building relationships not only within your chapter, but also with others within the community. These organizations have shown true partnerships with other organizations as well as overall community participation.

Recognition Status: Full

Judicial History

April 19, 2023 - Expectations for Membership and Recognition Policy

Adjudication Type: Resolution Meeting

Responsible Violations: Misconduct Related to Student Organizations or Groups (Prohibited Conduct - public urination, garbage)

Sanctions: Written Reprimand; Chapter complete Decision Making Course; Facilitated dialogue on Culture of Respect (for chapter & facility); Creation of Gorge Stewardship Course with requirement for New Member Education and all current members; Chapter host workshop with Cornell Sustainability; Chapter to create transition document for all leadership roles; Sustainability Plan for Chapter.

April 21, 2020- Expectations for Membership and Recognition Policy

Adjudication Type: Informal Resolution/Greek Judicial Board, 5/17/2021.

Responsible Violations: Collective responsibility for the behavior of the members inside and outside of the Chapter house. Also, exterior neatness of the premises, the avoidance of unreasonable noise levels and compliance with related local laws.

Sanctions: Must provide proof of the plans the chapter had already put in motion (the sustainability committee, increased recycling bins, education materials, etc. Additionally, the chapter must submit information on what precisely the judicial consequences will be if an individual is caught throwing trash into the gorge.

March 8, 2020 - Event Management Guidelines Policy

Adjudication Type: Informal Resolution, April 24, 2020.

Responsible Violations: Over Occupancy for Assembly Space, Insufficient Sober Monitors, Prevent Overcrowding.

Sanctions: Chapter conducted various trainings.

January 22, 2018 - Recognition Policy, Event Management Guidelines Policy

Adjudication Type: Fraternity & Sorority Review Board, February 7, 2018.

Responsible Violations: Hazing Violation, Recruitment or New Member Function, Hard Liquor (shots and mixed drinks), Selling or Giving Alcohol to Individuals Less Than 21 Years of Age.

Sanctions: Meet with OSFL, Probationary Recognition, Revised Orientation Plan, and Social Probation.

Dr. Susan H. Murphy, Sorority & Fraternity Award

2019 Outstanding Commitment to Programming

Providing inspiring and influential programming to members is paramount to membership growth and success. Winners in this category have engaged with tough topics, provided space for impactful conversation, and innovated strategies to achieve the learning outcomes of a program. These programs have been member specific, organizational partnerships, and/or events open to the entire Cornell/Ithaca community.

Sorority and Fraternity Scholarships

Gordon J. Whiting/Sigma Chi Scholarship

This award is need-based and intended for Greek undergraduates who demonstrate leadership qualities or hold a leadership position in their respective chapter. Students who qualify for grant and work-study through the Cornell Financial Aid Office and demonstrate a significant leadership role in their chapter are eligible to self-nominate. Students who have grant and self-help components in their financial aid package and are selected based on rank order established by the chapter and alumni. Awards are for the following year and graduating seniors are not eligible to apply.

Recognition Status: Full

2019 Outstanding Commitment to Leadership & Accountability

Fraternal organizations should commit themselves to promoting the personal and professional development of their members through accountability to values. A well-functioning organization can be attributed to strong leadership and engaged members who are capable of holding their peers accountable for their actions. Winners in this category have shown integrity through respect for others, courage by empowering all members to lead, and honor by taking responsibility to hold individuals accountable for their actions. These organizations integrate and promote personal and professional leadership development and harm reduction strategies into organization events and activities in an effective manner.

Dedication to promoting an inclusive community is central to the Cornell Sorority & Fraternity community values. Community incorporates friendship, love, loyalty, and diversity. Organizations should show dedication to inclusive practices in programming and training initiatives. Dr. Susan H. Murphy, Sorority & Fraternity Award

2019 Outstanding Commitment to Leadership & Accountability

Fraternal organizations should commit themselves to promoting the personal and professional development of their members through accountability to values. A well-functioning organization can be attributed to strong leadership and engaged members who are capable of holding their peers accountable for their actions. Winners in this category have shown integrity through respect for others, courage by empowering all members to lead, and honor by taking responsibility to hold individuals accountable for their actions. These organizations integrate and promote personal and professional leadership development and harm reduction strategies into organization events and activities in an effective manner.

Martha P. & Lucian L. Leape Scholarship

This award is need-based and intended for Greek undergraduates who demonstrate leadership qualities or hold a leadership position in their respective chapter. Students who qualify for grant and work-study through the Cornell Financial Aid Office and demonstrate a significant leadership role in their chapter are eligible to self-nominate. Students who have grant and self-help components in their financial aid package and are selected based on rank order established by the chapter and alumni. Awards are for the following year and graduating seniors are not eligible to apply.
